facts.text: Writ Petition No. 77 of 1972 filed in Original Jurisdiction under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for a writ in the nature of habeas corpus.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petition No. 77 of 1972. Under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for a writ in the nature of habeas companypus.

facts.text: K. Dhingra appeared for the petitioner.

anchor.surface_text: K. Dhingra, for the petitioner. Dilip Sinha and G. S. Chatterjee, for the respondent.

facts.text: Dilip Sinha and G. S. Chatterjee appeared for the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: K. Dhingra, for the petitioner. Dilip Sinha and G. S. Chatterjee, for the respondent. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Shelat, J.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Shelat, J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Shelat, J. The District Magistrate, Howrah passed on June 12, 1971 the impugned order of detention

facts.text: District Magistrate, Howrah passed detention order on June 12, 1971 under sub-section 1 read with sub-section 3 of section 3 of the West Bengal Prevention of Violent Activities Act, 1970.

anchor.surface_text: The District Magistrate, Howrah passed on June 12, 1971 the impugned order of detention under sub-s.  1  read with sub-s.  3  of s. 3 of the West Bengal  Prevention of Violent Activities  Act, 1970 directing the petitioners detention thereunder.

facts.text: Detention order directed petitioner's detention to prevent acting in manner prejudicial to maintenance of public order.

anchor.surface_text: The order stated that the District Magistrate was satisfied that it was necessary to do so in order to prevent the petitioner from acting in a manner prejudicial to the maintenance of public order.

facts.text: Petitioner arrested on June 13, 1971 and detained in Dum Dum Central Jail.

anchor.surface_text: On June 13, 1971, the petitioner was accordingly arrested and detained in Dum Dum Central Jail.

facts.text: On 17-8-70 at about 02.00 hours, petitioner and associates Bhaja alias Tarapada Ghosh, Bablu, Kartic and others attacked members of R.G. Party near Jatadhari Park by hurling bombs, hurled more when chased, escaped, disturbing public order.

anchor.surface_text: The grounds of detention served on the petitioner at the time of his arrest read as follows On 17-8-70 at about 02.00 hours, you and your associates Bhaja alias Tarapada Ghosh, Bablu, Kartic and others attacked the members of R.G. Party who were on duty near Jatadhari Park by hurling bombs towards them.

facts.text: On 10-4-71 at about 16.00 hours, petitioner and associates armed with sword assaulted Basudeb Laha of 56/18, Banarjee Bagan Lane at Sambhu Halder Lane near Jatadhari Park, causing injuries, terrorised public by brandishing sword.

anchor.surface_text: When chased by them, you and your associates again hurled bombs towards them and managed to escape and thereby disturbed public order. On 10-4-71 at about 16.00 hours, you and your associates being armed with sword assaulted one Basudeb Laha of 56/18, Banarjee Bagan Lane.

facts.text: On 1-5-71 at 15.00 hours, petitioner and associates Tapan, Kartic and others armed with bombs and deadly weapons demanded money from Banshi Show of 28, Haraganj Road, P.S. Malipanchghora, assaulted him when refused, terrorised locals and shop keepers by throwing bombs, causing panic.

anchor.surface_text: at Sambhu Halder Lane near Jatadhari Park causing injuries on his person. When objected by the members of the public, you also terrorised them by brandishing the sword. On 1-5-71 at 15.00 hours, you and your associates Tapan, Kartic and others being armed with bombs and other deadly weapons demanded money from one Banshi Show of 28, Haraganj Road, P.S. Malipanchghora.

facts.text: Grounds of detention 1 and 3 not disputed as falling under clause (d) of section 3(2), being offences under Explosive Substances Act, 1908, disturbing public order.

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed that the petitioners- alleged activities set out in grounds   1   and  3  of the said grounds of detention fell under cl.  d  being offences under the Explosive Substances Act, 1908, and also being such that they did or were likely to disturb public order.

facts.text: Petitioner contended that ground No. 2 (sword assault) constitutes offence under s.324 IPC, not punishable with death, life imprisonment or 7 years, not under Arms Act or Explosive Substances Act, thus extraneous ground invalidating order.

anchor.surface_text: The only companytention raised for our determination was that activities set out in ground No.  2 , namely, causing injuries with a sword. would companyystitute an offence under s. 324 of the Penal Code, an offence neither punishable with death, number life imprisonment, number imprisonment for a term of seven years.

facts.text: No notification issued under section 4 of the Arms Act, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: It, however, appears that numbersuch numberification as companytemplated by S. 4 of the 1959 Act has been issued.

facts.text: Notification No. 787 PL dated March 9, 1923 issued under s.15 of Indian Arms Act, 1878 by Political Police Department.

anchor.surface_text: But, in 1923 such a numberification bearing reference No. Political  Police  Department Notification No. 787 PL, dated March 9, 1923 was issued under s. 15 of the earlier Indian Arms Act, XI of 1878, which was in terms similar to S. 4 of the present Act.

facts.text: Arms Act, 1878 (Act XI of 1878) repealed by section 46(1) of Arms Act, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Sec. 46 1  of the Arms Act, 1959 repealed the preceding Act of 1878.

facts.text: Section 46(2) of Arms Act, 1959 saves licences granted under repealed Act of 1878.

anchor.surface_text: Its sub-s.  2  provides that numberwithstanding such repeal and without prejudice to ss. 6 and 24 of the General Clauses Act, X of 1897 a licence granted under the repealed Act and in force immediately before the companyencement of the new Act shall companytinue, unless sooner revoked, for the unexpired period for which it had been granted or renewed.

facts.text: Sword is 'arms' under section 2(1)(c) of Arms Act, 1959 as sharp-edged and other deadly weapons.

anchor.surface_text: Under S. 2 1   c  of the Arms Act, the word arms inter alia means articles of any description designed or adapted as weapons for offence or defence, and includes firearms, sharpedged and other deadly weapons. A sword is thus arms I within the meaning of this definition.

facts.text: Offence in ground No. 2 occurred in 1970, after repeal of Arms Act, 1878.

anchor.surface_text: Though the possession of and carrying a sword were alleged to have been companyymitted in 1970, that is, after the repeal of the Arms Act, 1878, the said numberification of 1923 issued under the repealed Act would, despite its repeal, companytinue to be in force

facts.text: 1923 notification continues in force under Arms Act, 1959 by virtue of sections 6 and 24 of General Clauses Act, 1897.

anchor.surface_text: The companybined effect of ss. 6 and 24 of the General Clauses Act is that the said numberification of 1923 issued under s. 15 of the Act of 1878 number only companytinued to operate but has. to be deemed to have been enacted under the new Act.

facts.text: Court rejected petitioner's contention that ground No. 2 does not fall under clause (d) of section 3(2) as it is offence under Arms Act, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: The companytention in our view has numbersubstance as the offence alleged in ground No.  2  would fall under cl.  d  of s. 1  2  of the Act inasmuch as it will be one, punishable under the Arms Act, LIV of 1959.

concepts.interpretation: Grounds of detention must fall under this clause involving offences under Arms Act or Explosive Substances Act disturbing public order.

anchor.surface_text: for a writ in the nature of habeas companypus. K. Dhingra, for the petitioner. Dilip Sinha and G. S. Chatterjee, for the respondent.

concepts.unlisted_description: Writ petition under Art.32 challenging detention.

issues.text: Whether the activities set out in ground No. 2, namely causing injuries with a sword, constitute an offence under s. 324 of the Penal Code not falling under cl. (d) of s. 3(2) of the West Bengal Prevention of Violent Activities Act, 1970, thereby rendering the impugned detention order invalid as extraneous.

anchor.surface_text: The only contention raised for our determination was that activities set out in ground No.  2 , namely, causing injuries with a sword. would constitute an offence under s. 324 of the Penal Code, an offence neither punishable with death, nor life imprisonment, nor imprisonment for a term of seven years.

issues.text: Whether the 1923 notification issued under s. 15 of the Indian Arms Act, 1878 (repealed by the Arms Act, 1959) continues to be operative under the Arms Act, 1959 by virtue of sections 6 and 24 of the General Clauses Act.

anchor.surface_text: The question is, whether Act XI of 1878 having been repealed, the said notification issued under s. 15 thereof can still be said to be operative ? Sec. 46 1  of the Arms Act, 1959 repealed the preceding Act of 1878.

arguments.claim: Activities in ground No. 2 (causing injuries with a sword) constitute an offence under s.324 IPC, neither punishable with death, life imprisonment nor 7 years, nor under Arms Act or Explosive Substances Act, thus extraneous ground invalidating detention order

anchor.surface_text: The only contention raised for our determination was that activities set out in ground No.  2 , namely, causing injuries with a sword. would constitute an offence under s. 324 of the Penal Code, an offence neither punishable with death, nor life imprisonment, nor imprisonment for a term of seven years.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: , any offence punishable with death or imprisonment for life or imprisonment for a term extending to seven years or more or any offence under the Arm

arguments.court_reasoning: Contention has no substance as offence falls under cl. (d) s.3(2) punishable under Arms Act 1959

arguments.claim: Offence in ground No. 2 falls under cl. (d) of s.3(2) as punishable under Arms Act 1959

anchor.surface_text: The contention in our view has no substance as the offence alleged in ground No.  2  would fall under cl.  d  of s. 3 2  of the Act inasmuch as it will be one, punishable under the Arms Act, LIV of 1959.

arguments.claim: Sword qualifies as 'arms' under s.2(1)(c) of Arms Act 1959 including sharp-edged and other deadly weapons

anchor.surface_text: Under S. 2 1   c  of the Arms Act, the word arms inter alia means articles of any description designed or adapted as weapons for offence or defence, and includes firearms, sharpedged and other deadly weapons. A sword is thus arms I within the meaning of this definition.

arguments.claim: Possession or carrying of notified arms like sword without licence in specified area is offence punishable under s.25(1)(b) Arms Act 1959 with up to 3 years imprisonment

anchor.surface_text: Sec. 25  1   b  provides that whoever acquires, has in his possession or carries in any place specified by notification under s. 4 any arms of such class or description as have been specified in that notification in contravention of that section shall be punishable with imprisonment for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine or with both.

arguments.claim: No notification issued under s.4 Arms Act 1959 but 1923 notification under s.15 Arms Act 1878 (similar provision) continues in force

anchor.surface_text: It, however, appears that no such notification as contemplated by S. 4 of the 1959 Act has been issued. But, in 1923 such a notification bearing reference No. Political  Police  Department Notification No. 787 PL, dated March 9, 1923 was issued under s. 15 of the earlier Indian Arms Act, XI of 1878, which was in terms similar to S. 4 of the present Act.

arguments.claim: 1923 notification continues despite repeal of 1878 Act by s.46 Arms Act 1959 via ss.6 and 24 General Clauses Act; deemed enacted under 1959 Act as provisions re-enacted with no contrary intention

anchor.surface_text: Sec. 46 1  of the Arms Act, 1959 repealed the preceding Act of 1878. ... The combined effect of ss. 6 and 24 of the General Clauses Act is that the said notification of 1923 issued under s. 15 of the Act of 1878 not only continued to operate but has to be deemed to have been enacted under the new Act.

arguments.claim: 1923 notification operative even for 1970 offence post-1959 Act as deemed under s.4 Arms Act 1959 by GCA s.24

anchor.surface_text: Though the possession of and carrying a sword were alleged to have been committed in 1970, that is, after the repeal of the Arms Act, 1878, the said notification of 1923 issued under the repealed Act would, despite its repeal, continue to be in force

arguments.claim: Precedent in Chief Inspector of Mines v. Lala Karam Chand Thapar supports construction that regulations/notifications under repealed Act continue under re-enacted Act via GCA s.24, valid even for offences

anchor.surface_text: This was the construction placed upon these two sections by this Court in the Chief Inspector of Mines v. Lala Karam Chand Thapar... Regulations framed under the repealed Act continue in force and are deemed to have been made under the provisions so re-enacted, and must be so construed as to have continuity of force

holdings.text: The contention in our view has no substance as the offence alleged in ground No. 2 would fall under cl. d of s. 3(2) of the Act inasmuch as it will be one, punishable under the Arms Act, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: The contention in our view has no substance as the offence alleged in ground No.  2  would fall under cl.  d  of s. 3  2  of the Act inasmuch as it will be one, punishable under the Arms Act, LIV of 1959.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Offence involves carrying sword (arms) without licence in notified area, punishable under s.25(1)(b) Arms Act 1959 as notification continues via GCA ss.6,24.

holdings.text: Under S. 2(1)(c) of the Arms Act, the word 'arms' inter alia means ... sharp-edged and other deadly weapons. A sword is thus arms within the meaning of this definition.

anchor.surface_text: Under S. 2 1   c  of the Arms Act, the word arms inter alia means articles of any description designed or adapted as weapons for offence or defence, and includes firearms, sharpedged and other deadly weapons. A sword is thus arms I within the meaning of this definition.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of statutory definition of 'arms' to sword as sharp-edged deadly weapon.

holdings.text: The combined effect of ss. 6 and 24 of the General Clauses Act is that the said notification of 1923 issued under s. 15 of the Act of 1878 not only continued to operate but has to be deemed to have been enacted under the new Act.

anchor.surface_text: The combined effect of ss. 6 and 24 of the General Clauses Act is that the said notification of 1923 issued under s. 15 of the Act of 1878 not only continued to operate but has. to be deemed to have been enacted under the new Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Repeal by Arms Act 1959 s.46 does not affect prior notifications under identical s.15 of 1878 Act per GCA s.6 (prior operations) and s.24 (deemed under re-enacted provisions); no contrary intention.

holdings.text: Though the possession of and carrying a sword were alleged to have been committed in 1970, that is, after the repeal of the Arms Act, 1878, the said notification of 1923 issued under the repealed Act would, despite its repeal, continue to be in force and its provisions would be deemed to have been enacted under the new Act by virtue of s. 24 of the General Clauses Act.

anchor.surface_text: Though the possession of and carrying a sword were alleged to have been committed in 1970, that is, after the repeal of the Arms Act, 1878, the said notification of 1923 issued under the repealed Act would, despite its repeal, continue to be in force

holdings.reasoning_summary: Deemed enactment under s.4 Arms Act 1959 makes 1923 notification applicable to post-repeal offences.

holdings.text: The offence thus fell under the Arms Act, 1959, and that being so, acts set out in ground No. 2 were covered by cl. d of S. 3(2) of the Act.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulatively, sword carrying offence under continuing notification violates Arms Act, qualifies under WBPVAA s.3(2)(d) as disturbing public order.
